monogr.title: A forme of common prayer, together with an order of fasting: for the auerting of Gods heauie visitation vpon many places of this kingdome, and for the obtaining of his blessings vpon vs : The prayers are to be read euery Wednesday during this visitation. Set forth by his Maiesties authority
monogr.author: Church of England

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
WEe be taught by many and sundry examples of holy Scriptures, that vpon occasion of particular punishments, afflictions and perils, which God of his most iust iudgement hath sometimes sent among his people, to shew his wrath against sin, and to call them to repentance, and to the redresse of their liues, all men ought to bee provoked and stirred vp to more feruencie and diligence in Prayer, Fasting and Almes-deeds, to a more
deepe consideration of their consciences, to ponder their vnthankefulnesse and forgetfulnesse of Gods mercifull benefits towards them, with crauing of pardon for the time past, and to aske his assistance for the time to come, to live more godly, and so to be defended and deliuered from all further perils and dangers.2. Sam. 24.14. So King David in the time of Plague and Pestilence which ensued upon his vaine numbring of the people, prayed vnto God with wonderfull feruency, confessing his fault, desiring God to spare the people, and rather to turne his ire to himward, who had chiefly offended in that transgression. The like was done by the vertuous Kings,2. Chr. 20.5 2. Reg. 19.1. Ionah 3. Iosaphat and Ezechias, in their distresse of warres and forreigne invasions. So did the King and
people of Nineue, and Hester, Ester 14.13 Dan. 9.4. fall to humble prayers in like perils of their people. So did Daniel in his captiuity, and many other moe in their troubles. Now therefore calling to minde, that God hath beene prouoked by vs to visit vs at this present with the Plague and other grieuous diseases: It hath beene thought meet to excite and stirre vp all godly people within this Realme, to pray earnestly and heartily to God to forgiue vs our sinnes, and consequently to turne away his deserued wrath from vs, and to restore vs to his gracious fauour, and to our bodily health. And although it is euery Christian mans duty, of his owne deuotion to pray at all times: yet for that the corrupt nature of man is so slothfull and negligent herein, he hath need by often and sundry
meanes to be stirred vp and put in remembrance of his duty. For the effectuall accomplishment whereof, it is thought meet that this order of Prayer following should at this time bee published, being such as shall be vsed by the Minister in the Church, and may by euery man in his priuate family.
